I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is one of the major development partners in the 
education sector in Nepal. ADB has been actively involved in supporting the Government of 
Nepal in the ongoing School Sector Reform Program and Skills for Employment Project.1 The 
capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Strengthening  Higher  Engineering 
Education is an outcome of a series of discussions with the government since April 2011.2 The 
TA responds to the government’s high priority in improving engineering and technical education 
in higher education, and increasing access to high quality engineering and technical education 
in far and mid-western regions that were severely affected by civil strife. The government 
concurred with the design and monitoring framework, implementation arrangements, costs, 
financing plan, and terms of reference in October 2011. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Progress in development. Nepal is among the least developed countries in the world—
its human development index was ranked 157 out of 187 countries in 20113 and 31% of its 
population was living below the national poverty line in 2004.4 Its landlocked geographic location, 
protracted sociopolitical transition, and susceptibility to natural disaster are the main challenges 
for the country’s growth. Nonetheless, Nepal has made progress in reducing its poverty, and 
improving access to basic education, health, and clean water. The recent political transition from 
a monarchy to a republic after a decade-long violent insurgence has triggered aspirations for 
social  changes.  Responding  to  this,  the  government’s  strategy  envisages  tangible 
improvements in the living standards of the poor, disadvantaged, and socially excluded sections 
of the population. 
 
3.  Potential  for  growth  and  human  resource  development  needs.  Nepal  has  four 
distinct  advantages  for  economic  growth:  (i)  its  strategic  location  between  India  and  the 
People’s Republic of China, whose continued high growth can trigger untapped robust growth in 
Nepal;  (ii)  natural  resources,  including  hydropower  and  biodiversity,  which  have  enormous 
potential given the huge needs for power and energy in South Asia; (iii) tourism, a major 
economic force that can fuel investments; and (iv) a young population that supplies about 
450,000 new entrants to the labor market annually. The contribution from overseas Nepalese 
workers to the economy is substantial, with remittances over 20% of the gross domestic product.  
 
4.  Turning  the  human  resource  potential  into  socially  inclusive  and  environmentally 
sustainable  economic  development  will  require  a  strong  human  resource  base.  There  is 
massive need to develop the skills, capacity, and entrepreneurship of the young population to 
avoid social tension from increasing youth unemployment. This will require transforming the 
education system to focus on quality, relevance, and employability so that the labor market can 
move up the value chain from the current heavy reliance on low level skills. The role of higher 
education is crucial since the country must develop human resources that can lead the nation’s 
economic development and social transformation—by addressing the challenges from massive

infrastructure  development,  and  natural  disasters.  Nepal  also  needs  to  improve  the 
competitiveness of Nepalese workers in the region and globally.  
 
5.  Challenges in higher education. Nepal has made significant progress in primary and 
secondary  education.  The  number  of  students  completing  and/or  passing  the  secondary 
education exam is rising fast—increasing by more than 100% from 113,020 in 2005 to 259,916 
in  2009.  Higher  education  has  also  expanded  rapidly,  particularly  through  private  sector 
providers in response to the unmet demand. Total enrollment increased 20 times from a very 
low base of 17,000 students in 1970 to 351,900 students enrolled in 2009. There are six 
universities  and  three  higher  education  academies  (medical  schools),  with  89  constituent 
campuses and 749 affiliated campuses. Among the total 749 affiliated campuses, 218 are 
community campuses registered under the University Grant Commission that receive grants 
support.  The  remaining  531  campuses  are  private.  However,  access  to  higher  education 
remains low. Only 10% of the corresponding age cohort is enrolled in higher education, in 
comparison to the world average of 26%.  
 
6.  Disparities in access to higher education are large across different sex, income levels, 
and geographic locations. Female enrollment is only 30% of the total enrollment and is often 
biased toward certain fields (e.g., education and nursing). Female enrollment in engineering 
remains  low,  at  15%.  The  enrollment  from  the  poorest  quintile,  mostly  consisting  of 
disadvantaged social groups, is negligible. The urban–rural disparity is significant, with the 
highest concentration of institutions and students in Kathmandu Valley, while the mid- and far-
west development regions significantly lag in terms of the number of institutions and student 
enrollment. 
 
7.  The  relevance  and  quality  of  higher  education  is  an  increasing  problem.  Current 
institutional  and  student  expansions  are  not  based  on  job  market  perspective  or  national 
development needs. Students enrolled in education, management, and the humanities and 
social sciences comprised 85% of all students in higher education in FY2008 while science, 
technology, and engineering represented less than 10% of students. Concern is growing over 
the high level of dropouts and unemployed graduates from humanities and social science 
programs. The quality of higher education is generally poor, with an average passing rate of 
38% at bachelor’s level and 40% at master’s level. This is attributed to the lack of quality 
assurance mechanisms, a poor learning and teaching environment, the low level of faculty 
development  and  retention,  weak  administrative  capacity,  and  lack  of  linkages  between 
education and the world of work.  
 
8.  At the core of the issues are weak governance and lack of financing for higher education 
institutions. Higher education received 9.9% of the total education budget in FY2010. The lack 
of a clear national framework to guide and regulate higher education institutions has led to less 
effective  institutional  management,  low  output  efficiency,  and  lack  of  monitoring  and 
accountability. In particular, university system expansion through affiliation is becoming an issue 
because of the lack of effective quality control and the constraints to innovation at campus level. 
 
9.  Ongoing  higher  education  reform. While there  is  no  explicit  policy framework  or 
strategy for higher education, the government has implemented two higher education reform 
projects with the support of the World Bank, focusing on incremental reforms through the 
University Grant Commission and directly with universities and colleges. The ongoing Second 
Higher Education Project, 2007–2014 aims at (i) enhanced quality, efficiency, and relevance of 
higher education through a set of systemic reforms, and incentives to selected institutions; and

3 
(ii) improved access for academically qualified students from disadvantaged groups in higher 
education and higher secondary education. 
 
10.  Focus on engineering and technical education. There is a large unmet demand for 
engineering and technical education at higher education level. Despite the recent expansion in 
higher education enrollment, the development has been lopsided toward humanities and social 
science. Engineering graduates are in short supply to meet market demand—mainly because of 
the  limited  number  of  graduates  and  emigration  of  graduates  for  better  job  opportunities 
overseas. Concern is also growing over the quality of graduates in terms of relevance to 
national development priorities, mainly because of the lack of research facilities, practical and 
problem-oriented research, and linkage to the world of work. Therefore, enhancing engineering 
and technical education is an urgent need. Quality engineering and technical education at 
higher education is crucial to supply a qualified workforce to support growing public and private 
investments  in  transportation,  energy,  municipal  infrastructure,  tourism,  and  other  priority 
sectors. It will also lead innovations through industry linkage via collaboration in research and 
development, thus contributing to the economy’s productivity and efficiency. Close linkages 
between  industry  and  universities  can  create  opportunities  for  cost-sharing  and  innovative 
public–private partnership (PPP) arrangements.  
  
11.  Linkage to country partnership strategy. The TA is fully aligned with ADB’s country 
partnership  strategy  for  2010–20125 and  the  government’s  priorities6 given  the  strategic 
importance  of  education  in  reducing  poverty  and  social  exclusion,  enhancing  economic 
opportunities, and contributing to economic growth. ADB has supported the government in 
strengthening  school  education  by  improving  quality  and  reducing  disparity  as  well  as  in 
developing skills to increase employability. ADB also plans to develop a follow-up project in 
technical and vocational education and training. The TA complements ADB’s ongoing and 
planned investments, especially by aiming at higher education and exploring ways to strengthen 
the backward linkage to secondary school education and skills development.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
12.  The TA will support the Ministry of Education and other stakeholders in identifying a 
strategy to enhance higher engineering education in Nepal. The TA will work with the Institute of 
Engineering (IOE) as a model case in improving the quality and relevance of higher education in 
response to market demand and national development priorities through improved governance, 
management capacity, and industry linkages.7 The TA will assist the stakeholders in identifying 
key engineering disciplines to be strengthened, considering labor market demand as well as 
national development priorities. It will also support IOE in refining its midterm strategic plan (i) to 
increase access to engineering and technical education by establishing regional campuses in 
the far-western and mid-western development regions, which are home to excluded groups8 and

7  IOE has been selected as the model institute because it (i) is the premier engineering education institution in 
Nepal, with four constituent campuses and 17 affiliated colleges (10 of them are private); (ii) produces teachers for 
its own colleges as well as other universities and colleges; (iii) has autonomy under the Tribhuvan University 
system, so it may introduce new rules and arrangements to a certain extent; and (iv) has demonstrated good

4   
conflict-affected regions; and (ii) introduce measures to enhance the relevance and quality of 
higher  engineering  education,  including  continuous  professional  development,  an  improved 
research  environment,  better  utilization  of  information  and  communication  technology,  and 
university–industry linkages. Feasible PPP arrangements will be actively explored as ways to 
improve the relevance and quality as well as financing options for higher engineering education. 
The TA will support IOE to identify areas for improvement in governance, and prepare feasibility 
studies. The TA will also support necessary due diligence for the future investment. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the TA will be improved quality of higher engineering education to meet 
the emerging labor market needs. The outcome of the TA will be that the engineering and 
technical education system is designed toward greater market responsiveness. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The activities of the TA will be carried out through a consultative process involving key 
stakeholders to ensure that the recommendations are developed based on consensus. The TA 
will conduct surveys, workshops, and focus group discussions to incorporate views from six 
types  of  stakeholders:  (i)  students,  (ii)  parents,  (iii)  teachers,  (iv)  policy  makers  (both 
government and education institutions), (v) the private sector, and (vi) development partners. 
Inputs from stakeholders will be analyzed and consolidated into the following five outputs:  
 
15.  Output 1 will formulate an implementation plan for improved access to and quality of the 
engineering  program.  Under  this  output,  the  TA  will  examine  various  aspects  of  higher 
engineering education. In particular, it will explore options and develop detailed implementation 
plans to expand access and improve quality of higher education and its relevance to labor 
market demand and national development priorities. This output will produce two sub-outputs. 
First, a labor market analysis, focusing on engineering disciplines, to project the number of 
graduates the labor market will require in specific disciplines and to identify priority disciplines 
for strengthening or establishment. The labor market trend and practices in employment of 
women and people from excluded groups will also be assessed. Second, a program for the 
professional development of engineering faculty and an inclusive enrollment strategy for women 
and students from excluded groups will be developed.  
 
16.  Output 2 will prepare a financing program for the expansion and improvement of the 
engineering education. This output will support feasibility studies for campus expansion, the 
establishment of an information and communication technology (ICT) facility, improvement of 
the research environment, and diversified financing options. The feasibility studies and financing 
plan will be submitted to the government and other potential funding sources for consideration.   
 
17.  Output  3  will  improve  the  capacity  of  the  Institute  of  Engineering  and  participating 
institutions  in  human  resource  and  financial  management,  and  administration  of  academic 
institutions. Under this output, existing IOE policy, regulation, and management capacity and 
practices  will  be  reviewed  and  areas  for  improvement  will  be  identified.  Regional  and 
international  best  practices  will  be  discussed  and  adopted  as  appropriate.  The  output  will 
recommend  policy  and  regulatory  changes,  which  will  be  consulted  with  stakeholders 
                                                                                                                                                       
the nation’s development, i.e., women, Dalits, Adivasi Janajatis, Madhesis, Muslims, people living with disabilities, 
and people of geographically remote areas.

5 
(government, Tribhuvan University, IOE, the private sector, and other engineering colleges) 
before being finalized in a governance improvement plan.  
 
18.  Output 4 will complete a study of various academe–industry–private sector partnership 
arrangements. This output will explore feasible options for higher engineering education to 
strengthen industry linkage and collaboration with the private sector. Proposals may include 
research and development facility sharing, effective operation of a technology transfer center, 
industry-specific  training  programs,  and  other  private  sector  partnerships.  Cost-sharing 
arrangements will be actively explored. Selection of best practices will be based on interest from 
private sector partners.  
  
19.  Output  5  will  support  the  stakeholders  in  effective  planning,  management,  and 
coordination  for  the  ensuing  project.  This  output  will  assist  IOE  to  develop  adequate 
implementation arrangements for effective planning, management, and coordination of the TA 
as well as ensuing project activities. This output will also support other due diligence activities 
for a follow-on investment project in accordance with ADB requirements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $550,000 equivalent. The government has requested 
ADB to finance $550,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government and IOE will provide 
in-kind contributions such as office accommodation, staff time, and other coordination support. 
Cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  will  be  the  executing  agency.  IOE  will  be  the 
implementing agency. IOE will also act as an anchor and will closely involve other higher 
education institutions. A TA steering committee chaired by the secretary of the MOE will be 
established, with the dean of IOE as the member-secretary. Representatives from the University 
Grants  Commission,  Ministry  of  Finance,  National  Planning  Commission,  Federation  of 
Nepalese  Chambers  of  Commerce  and  Industries,  Confederation  of  Nepalese  Industries, 
Engineering Association, and Banking Association will serve as members. Other members may 
be co-opted as needed. The steering committee will be responsible for providing overall policy 
direction, facilitating coordination among concerned government agencies, and seeking support 
from concerned public and private agencies.  
 
22.  The  TA  will  engage  consultants  to  provide  a  total  of  32  person-months  of  inputs 
(12 person-months of international and 20 person-months of national consultants). ADB will 
engage the consultants through a firm, using a simplified proposal for the quality- and cost-
based selection method as well as on an individual basis, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultant requirements 
and terms of reference are outlined in Appendix 3. All TA-financed goods will be procured in line 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over 9 months 
with expected commencement in March 2012 and completion in December 2012.

6   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $550,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Strengthening Higher Engineering Education, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overall Focus 
 
1.  The  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  (i)  identify  emerging  labor 
market needs, and prioritize disciplines and expertise most in demand, both for the internal and 
external  markets;  (ii)  identify  options  for  funding,  governance,  and  some  public–private 
partnership  (PPP)  arrangements;  and  (iii)  draw  on  ongoing  experience  and  identify  good 
practices to clearly articulate areas that need to be sustained. Finally, by incorporating the 
various findings, the TA will help prepare a feasibility study to consolidate  and selectively 
expand engineering and technical education. 
 
2.  The TA will focus on establishing two new engineering colleges—one in the mid-western 
region and the other in the far western region—strictly based on demand analysis. It will identify 
selected existing disciplines that need to be upgraded and strengthened based on labor market 
analysis. It will also identify potential opportunities for strengthening linkages between university 
and industry, such as a technology transfer office, collaborative research and development, and 
customized training programs, to enhance the relevance and quality of higher engineering 
education. These areas will seek possible PPP arrangements, which will contribute to  the 
effectiveness of engineering education and cost-sharing mechanism. Finally, the TA will explore 
possibilities for backward linkages to strengthen the training of trainers for skills development in 
infrastructure to support the value chain, linked with support to selected high-priority engineering 
disciplines.  The  TA  will  also  study  the  governance  structure  of  good  practices  in  higher 
education, such as the Indian Institute of Technology system, to draw implications on ensuring 
the good governance needed to produce high-quality engineering education in Nepal.  
 
B.  Consulting Services 
 
3.  The TA will be implemented over 9 months from the fielding of consultants, which is 
anticipated in March 2012. It will require 12 person-months of international (4 person-months on 
an individual basis) and 20 person-months of national (10 person-months on an individual basis) 
consulting services in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will recruit the team leader 
and  the  national  consultants  for  the  labor  market  economist,  fiduciary  risk  management, 
environment, social safeguards, and gender and social development specialists as individual 
consultants. The rest of the consultant inputs will be hired through a firm using a simplified 
technical proposal through the quality- and cost-based selection method (80:20).  
 
4.  Team leader/higher education specialist (international, 4 person-months, individual). 
The team leader will have more than 20 years of relevant experience in developing higher 
education  institutions  and  programs,  with  a  postgraduate  degree  in  pedagogy,  business 
administration,  public  administration,  science,  technology,  engineering,  or  other  related 
discipline.  Experience  in  a  developing  country  is  required.  The  team  leader  should  have 
experience in leading a high-quality engineering institution as well as in establishing and driving 
priority  reforms.  He  or  she  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall  organization  of  the  TA  by 
coordinating all the consultants and ensuring that all the outputs are available in accordance 
with the agreed schedule and outputs.  
 
5.  Deputy team leader/engineering education specialist (national, 5 person-months). 
The deputy team leader will have more than 20 years of experience in developing higher 
education program development in Nepal, in particular in engineering and technical education.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
Strong communications and coordination skills are required. The deputy team leader will be an 
expert, with experience in administration and management of engineering education. He or she 
will work and collaborate closely with the team leader. He or she will be responsible for ensuring 
effective coordination and implementation of the TA in line with its objectives. The deputy team 
leader will ensure that the Institute of Engineering (IOE), as the implementing agency, conducts 
proper stakeholder consultations on major outputs, and follows up as necessary to receive 
feedback from different stakeholder groups.   
  
6.  Public–private partnership specialist (international, 1 person-month). The consultant 
will have more than 10 years of experience in a PPP structuring and advisory role. He or she 
will have a proven track record in working on PPPs in engineering education, with a focus on 
research and development centers and business incubation. The PPP specialist will help to 
articulate options for PPPs in Nepal by drawing on experience in the region and/or from other 
relevant countries. In developing the options, the PPP specialist will organize focus group 
discussions with key stakeholders, including from the private and academic sectors. 
 
7.  Engineering education specialists (international, 4 person-months; national, 2 person-
months). The consultants will have at least 10 years of relevant experience in developing higher 
engineering education, with a focus on design and planning, implementation, coordination, and 
monitoring. Based on the priorities agreed in what disciplines to strengthen and what disciplines 
will  be  introduced  in  new  engineering  colleges,  the  specialists  will  assist  IOE  and  other 
stakeholders to develop detailed plans. The specialists should have up-to-date knowledge on 
equipment,  instructional  materials,  and  human  resource  needs.  The  specialists  will  be 
responsible for (i) designing a program to strengthen existing priority engineering disciplines 
and/or establishing selective new disciplines; (ii) identifying inputs (equipment, course materials, 
and professional development) required; and (iii) preparing detailed costing for the plan for the 
selected disciplines. 
 
8.  Human  resource  development  specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  The 
consultant will have at least 15 years of relevant experience in human resource development in 
higher education and the corporate sector, with a focus on technical and engineering areas. The 
consultant will make a projection of human resource needs, including a strategy to support the 
expansion and improvement of engineering education. The consultant will also draw on relevant 
international/regional  experience  in  establishing  a  training  center  to  address  issues  on 
continuous  professional  development  of  academic  and  administrative  staff  working  in 
engineering and technical education as well as industry linkages.   
 
9.  Labor market economists (international, 1 person-month; national,10 2 person-months, 
individual). The consultants will identify the trend in overall investment patterns in infrastructure 
in Nepal and the main overseas labor markets for Nepalese workers, and the link with emerging 
labor market needs for engineering graduates. The consultants will also analyze the supply side, 
i.e.,  engineering  colleges  and  universities.  The  consultants  will  complete  a  financial  and 
economic analysis of the proposed investment in higher engineering education following ADB 
guidelines.   
 
10.  Governance specialist (international, 1 person-month; national, 2 person-months). The 
consultant will have at least 10 years of relevant experience in analyzing regulatory framework 
and institutional capacity assessment, especially in higher education institutions and systems. 
                                                
10  A national consultant, engaged as a staff consultant for demand analysis for the engineering disciplines, will 
continue this work.

Appendix 3  13 
The consultant will draw on experiences from international good practices and regional best 
practices,  such  as the Indian  Institutes  of Technology,  to establish  critical  norms that  are 
essential to develop and maintain good governance in engineering institutions. In doing this, the 
consultant will review the experiences in Nepal to ascertain why some academic institutions 
have been able to maintain a high level of governance and others have not. The analysis will 
provide a basis to seek autonomy in financial, personnel, and academic affairs. 
 
11.  Fiduciary  risk  management  specialist (national, 2 person-months, individual). The 
consultant will have at least 10 years of experience in accounting, financial management, or 
project management. Experience with ADB’s financial management assessment is required. 
The consultant will review and analyze the funds flow mechanism and financial management 
arrangements of identified agencies, and recommend areas for improvements. In doing this, the 
consultant will draw on good practices from engineering institutions that have been successful in 
ensuring a high-quality financial management system. 
 
12.  Procurement specialist (national, 1 person-month). The consultant will have at least 
7 years of experience in public procurement, and projects funded by development partners. The 
consultant will conduct a procurement capacity assessment of the relevant agencies for a future 
investment  plan,  and  provide  recommendations  for  improvements  to  current  procurement 
practices. He or she will also help develop a procurement plan to support potential investments 
in engineering and technical education. The consultant will build on prior experience of the 
identified agencies and draw from relevant experience from other ADB projects and programs in 
Nepal.  
 
13.  Environment  specialist  (national,  2  person-months,  individual).  The  consultant  will 
have  at  least  10  years  of  relevant  experience  in  environmental  impact  assessments  and 
management  plans.  Experience  with  the  environmental  safeguard  work  of  ADB  or  other 
multilateral  investment  banks  is  required.  The  consultant  will  review  the  implications  on 
environmental aspects in line  with  ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). This will be 
particularly  critical  in  relation  to  future  construction  plans  and  their  implications  on  the 
environment. When more information regarding the construction plan becomes available to 
guide the initial categorization, the specialist’s terms of reference will be refined, including 
specific tasks. 
 
14.  Social safeguard specialist (national, 2 person-months, individual). The consultant will 
have at least 10 years of relevant experience in indigenous peoples and resettlement issues in 
Nepal. Experience in the social safeguard work of ADB or other multilateral investment banks is 
required. The consultant will review the implications of the TA’s proposed output and any 
ensuing project on indigenous peoples and resettlement, in line with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009). He or she will ensure adequate consultations with groups that may be 
affected by or benefit from the TA or an ensuing project. This will be particularly critical in 
relation to future construction plans and their implications on land acquisition and use. When 
more  information  regarding  the  construction  plans  becomes  available  to  guide  the  initial 
categorization, the specialist’s terms of reference will be refined, including specific tasks.  
 
15.  Gender and social development specialist (national, 2 person-months, individual). 
The consultant will have at least 10 years of experience in analyzing and assessing gender and 
social inclusion issues in Nepal. Experience with ADB’s gender work for project preparation is 
required. The consultant will (i) identify the beneficiaries and the social benefits of any potential 
investment; (ii) map out the targeted groups, with an emphasis on improving equity and ways to

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
enhance more equitable access to engineering and technical education; and (iii) develop a 
consultation and participation plan and a gender and social inclusion plan. 
 
C.   Reporting Requirements  
16.  The consultant team will deliver the following reports (time elapsed from the date of 
fielding consultants):  
(i)  Inception report (within 2 weeks) 
(ii)  Updated situation analysis (within 4 weeks) 
(iii)  Report on the proposed locations (within 4 weeks) 
(iv)  Labor market analysis in priority disciplines (within 12 weeks) 
(v)  Report on the proposed locations and disciplines for new engineering colleges 
(within 12 weeks) 
(vi)  Needs assessment on faculty, equipment, physical facilities, and research and 
development facilities (within 14 weeks) 
(vii)  Options paper on financing mechanisms (within 18 weeks) 
(viii)  Options paper on governance arrangements (within 20 weeks) 
(ix)  Options paper on the PPP modality (within 24 weeks) 
(x)  Draft design and monitoring framework (within 22 weeks) 
(xi)  Draft feasibility study (within 26 weeks) 
(xii)  Draft project design (within 30 weeks) 
(xiii)  Draft final project design (within 34 weeks) 
(xiv)  Final project design (within 36 weeks)
